 I think its very difficult to find a single cause for hostile attitudes towards gay people (particularly men). I say this because the use of such derogatory remarks is so pervasive in society today (well, at least in England where I live). From the time when we are children and learn to speak most of us get exposed to such use of language.... I'm sure the amount varies but I imagine most of us could recall hearing thr use of such words in the not to distant past.
 
 Comments by religious bodies are potentially very harmful, even more so than those from the sort of homophobes who actually do resort to violence against gay people. Often I feel because its is because of an almost blissful ignorance of the power of the language that is used by such groups. Saying things like the Bible says homosexuality is a sin could be seen as being harmless if everyone were considerate of others and had a live and let live attitude. But thats not reality, and to some people comments of this ilk can only serve to justify their hatred and fear of gays. 
 
 There is also the old veneer of respectability that comes from the opinions of people seen as being learned or teachers to those who look up to them.
 
 Homophobia is also allowed to go unpunished, even when published in some very public forums- certain elements of the British press are notorious for this (hello Sun and Daily Mail readers!) and its continual prescence only serves maintain and fuel the preconceived predjudices many hold. Even in day to day life it crops up- and when it does so it is difficult to confront particularly when its people who you know.
 
 I suppose its alot like racism..... there is a (small) group of people who are seen to be very different from the majority often with little knowing day to day contact between the two.
 
 It would be interesting to hear from some of our posters who object to homosexuality on religious grounds here...... but somehow I don't think we will.
